text: I'm John Marwood with the New York Times
in CNBC joined here at the democratic
national convention in Denver at the
pepsi center by congresswoman we're at a
Sanchez of California who is and has
been from the beginning a Clinton
supporter and super delegate at this
convention congresswoman Sanchez let me
ask you about a couple of constituencies
of Hillary Clinton's that Barack Obama
needs one is Latino voters the other is
women voters how well has he done so far
in healing the wounds of the primary and
getting those constituencies on his side
the polls seem to suggest is doing very
well with the Spanish well I think
Hispanics naturally will go that way
because they've been so upset by the
Bush administration and in particular
the policies of the Republicans in the
Congress with respect to immigration and
just really a lack of respect towards
our community but you know John McCain
is from Arizona he could pull some of
that Latino vote because he knows how to
talk to Latinas so I still believe that
Barack really needs to work on the
Latino vote in addition to that of
course women are still little
dissatisfied in a sense because I
believe that Barack hasn't made his case
to them and so this convention really
becomes about talking to those
disaffected voters at this point what is
your assessment of the extent of
tensions between Obama and Clinton both
at the level of the candidates the
principles themselves and their top
aides their operations and also at the
grass roots in terms of their delegates
and their supporters well I think what
you're going to see coming out of this
convention is it these are political
people the people here at the convention
the delegates whether they're super
delegates or the delegates elected
through the process through the states
are going our Democrats will be voting
the Democratic ticket but I think how
that translates and how these people
work out to bring in the vote for Barack
Obama becomes an important issue for him
in this in this convention that's why
the convention becomes so important for
him and I think on a personal level both
Barack and Hillary are professionals to
understand they really need each other
in order to get the Democrat into the
White House
so I think that's been okay I think
maybe the problem may have been yeah and
continues to be in somewhat by some of
the campaign people are the people
around them and we tend to see that a
lot in politics you know when the the
two principles are talking to each other
they understand what they need to get
done when there are layers between and
staff are talking to staff sometimes
they mess up the process some people
have said that the reconciliation
between those two camps should have been
further along than it is at this stage
as we enter the convention whose fault
is that well I think I I know if you
talk to Clinton supporters that they'll
say look she needs to get her debt paid
down this happens every time people help
each other you know the fact that
Brock's people have not helped when he
has this money machine behind him
suggests that he hasn't pushed his
people hard enough or his people haven't
pushed their donors and others hard
enough and I think that that is
something that really grates on some of
the Clinton supporters you know from
Hillary standpoint I think she's she's
gone to her supporters she's Astrid
donors to support Brock they have been
cutting checks to his campaign you know
money isn't everything but it's one of
the signals from each of the camps now
as you know Hillary Clinton's name is
going to be placed in nomination you've
indicated you're still supporting her
Hillary Clinton said a couple of weeks
ago that her supporters me to catharsis
to have her recognized for her campaign
and what it represented don fowler
former chair of the Democratic Party
said yesterday the dumbest thing he's
ever heard to have her name placed in
nomination because it's going to reopen
some of those divisions and not help
Barack Obama's message what's your
advice I don't know I love Don and he's
one of my mentors actually but I would
have to say I completely disagree with
him I mean what people in the party are
saying when they say those types of
things they don't see the disaffection
going on at the really grassroots level
and this needs to be handled this is why
this convention more than any other time
has become so important when when I look
at it quoting Hillary's name up and
she'll be speaking tonight on the
anniversary of women's suffrage this is
a very important issue for women when I
was out on the campaign trail for
Hillary I saw for example we went to
Texas it looked like Texas was a maker
break from out of nowhere came all these
women on their own funds coming into
town say what can I do from all over the
states so angry at the way the press of
treated Hillary at the way the party
seems to say we prefer a man still over
a female this is a very important issue
to acknowledge that women are important
because without women there is no
Democratic Party we've seen in the past
that divisions within a party can be
very harmful in the fall everybody
remembers Carter and Kennedy in 1980 how
concerned are you as a Democrat who
wants to win in November that the chill
the tension whatever you want to call it
between these two camps is going to be a
big problem in an election that now
looks closer than many Democrats thought
it was going to look about a month ago
yeah I you know I really still believe
that Barack Obama's to lose I mean he
but the fact of the matter is she should
be way ahead given what what the other
party has put up in the history of the
last eight years from the Republicans
the fact that everybody across the
nation is pretty angry at Bush and what
the Republicans did while they
controlled the Congress so why aren't we
further ahead why are we neck and neck
at this point in some of those poles and
and I and I again I think the issue is
that Barack Obama and his people need to
realize all the Democrats have to come
together and we all have to go out and
work for him but he has to make the ask
and as people have not done that
effectively target for me thanks so much
for joining us thank you I'm John
Harwood chief Washington correspondent
for CNBC
